page.title: 11Smarden W. - Village Church
page.content: The church of St. Michael the Archangel was built in the 14th/15th centuries. A list of rectors dates back to 1205. This church is remarkable for its proportions and grandeur of size. The aisleless nave, 36' across, dictates the use of a scissors beam roof and this has led to the church being named 'the barn of Kent'. Today the parishes of Smarden and Biddenden are under the care of the Rev. Roger Smith who was licensed in Sept. 1985. The times of service have to be adapted to the needs of both parishes. Smarden has a fair-sized choir, a keen band of bellringers, an active parochial church council and St. Michael's Guild (Ladies who raise funds for church restoration). The church is visited by tourists from many countries, attracted by its history and setting.
